titleStmt.title: Letter from Henry Irving to Samuel L. Clemens : an electronic text

sourceDesc.bibl: MS, Mark Twain Papers, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley (CU-MARK).

body.head:
Henry Irving to Samuel L. Clemens
31 March 1884 • New York, New York (MS: CU-MARK, UCLC 41956)

div1.p:
I have just got back from a very late rehearsal
Irving, along with his leading lady Ellen Terry and the Lyceum Company, were closing out their second American Tour. March 31st was opening night for a 24-night run at Lester Wallack's Star Theatre, featuring scenes from Much Ado About Nothing, Hamlet, Louis XI, Charles I, The Merchant of Venice, and The Lyons Mail. (Advertisements, New York Sun, 24 March 1884, 4; 12 April 1884, 4; and 22 April 1884, 4.) —5 o’clock—very tired—but there will be no rest till I get your autograph

This morning I am told it is a matter of life & deathThe prompt for this idea may have been his friend, Joseph Hatton, who also used a life or death trope in his letter. Joseph Hatton (1837-1907) was an English journalist, novelist and playwright, and a biographer of English actors Irving and Toole. He had met Clemens during his English sojourn in 1872-3, and recounts how at a dinner at Hezekiah Batemen's house a prominent tragedian (most likely Irving) delivered a humorous anecdote, which Hatton praised as “good English humour.” Sometime later while reading Mark Twain's Sketches, he discovered that Irving had retold a Mark Twain anecdote (Hatton, To-day in America: Studies for the Old World and the New (1881), 53. In 1884 Hatton was accompanying Irving on his second American tour as a buffer between Irving and the press, conducting his own interviews of the great tragedian in various cities on the tour. The collection of these interviews, along with scraps of gossip and travelogue, was published by Osgood in May 1884 as Irving's Impressions of America. —so don’t disappoint

closer.signed: H Irving.Clemens socialized with Irving and Hatton at the home of Hezekiah Bateman while on his English tour of 1872–3. (Hatton, To-day in America: Studies for the Old World and the New (1881), 53; Hatton, ed., Reminiscences of J. L. Toole (1889), 213; AD 19 Aug 1907, AutoMT3). Upon hearing of Irving's death Clemens sent the following telegram: “All our people mourn him. He earned their love & esteem at at his first coming & never lost it. He was endeared to me by a warm friendship of thirty-three years” (SLC to Macalister, 17 October 1905).
